name: Investment Risk Tolerance Assessment
description: Understand your comfort level with financial risk and investment volatility to guide your investment decisions.

questions.text: How do you typically react when your investment portfolio loses 10% of its value in a month?

options.text: I would panic and sell everything immediately
I would be very concerned and consider selling some investments
I would be worried but hold onto my investments
I would stay calm and stick to my long-term plan
I would see it as a buying opportunity and invest more

questions.text: What is your primary investment goal?

options.text: Preserve my capital with minimal risk
Generate steady income with some growth
Balance growth and income equally
Achieve significant growth over time
Maximize returns regardless of volatility

questions.text: How much investment experience do you have?

options.text: I'm completely new to investing
I have some basic knowledge but limited experience
I have moderate experience with various investments
I have extensive experience and understand market dynamics
I'm a sophisticated investor who actively manages complex portfolios

questions.text: If you had $10,000 to invest, which option would you choose?

options.text: 100% in savings accounts or CDs (guaranteed but low return)
80% bonds, 20% stocks (low risk, modest return)
50% bonds, 50% stocks (moderate risk and return)
20% bonds, 80% stocks (higher risk, higher potential return)
100% in high-growth stocks or startups (highest risk and potential)

questions.text: What is your investment time horizon?

options.text: Less than 2 years
2-5 years
5-10 years
10-20 years
More than 20 years

questions.text: How would losing 25% of your investment value affect your lifestyle?

options.text: It would be devastating and force major lifestyle changes
It would be very difficult and require some adjustments
It would be concerning but manageable
It would be disappointing but wouldn't affect my lifestyle
It wouldn't significantly impact me - I can afford the loss

categories.description: You have a conservative risk tolerance. You prioritize capital preservation and prefer stable, predictable returns over high growth potential.
recommendations: Focus on high-grade bonds and dividend-paying stocks
Consider money market funds and CDs for short-term goals
Limit equity allocation to 20-40% of portfolio
Review investments quarterly but avoid frequent changes

categories.description: You have a moderate risk tolerance. You seek a balance between growth and stability, accepting some volatility for better returns.
recommendations: Maintain a balanced portfolio of 50-70% stocks and 30-50% bonds
Diversify across domestic and international markets
Consider index funds for broad market exposure
Rebalance portfolio annually or when allocations drift significantly

categories.description: You have an aggressive risk tolerance. You're comfortable with high volatility in pursuit of maximum long-term growth potential.
recommendations: Allocate 80-100% to stocks with focus on growth companies
Consider emerging markets and sector-specific investments
Explore alternative investments like REITs or commodities
Stay disciplined during market downturns and avoid panic selling

summary.text: Based on your responses, your investment risk tolerance is {overall_risk_tolerance}. This means you should focus on building a portfolio that matches your comfort level with market volatility while working toward your financial goals.
